return.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to go or come back to a place where you were before
return.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: It was forty five minutes before she returned.
He left his country, never to return.
Are you planning to return to Spain?
I have just returned from five months in Zimbabwe.
return.translation[0].definitions[0].not: In everyday English, people usually say come back (=return to the place where the speaker is) or go back (=return to a different place from where the speaker is), rather than return:
It was forty five minutes before she came back.
Are you planning to go back to Spain?
return.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to give or send something back, or to put something back in its place
return.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Please complete the enclosed application form and return it in the envelope attached.
Carson returned the notebook to his pocket.
I returned the books to the library unread.
return.translation[0].definitions[1].not: In everyday English, people usually say that they take something back, put it back, or bring it back, rather than return it:
He put the key back in his pocket.
Did you take the books back to the library?
return.translation[0].definitions[2].def: if a feeling, situation etc returns, it starts to exist or happen again
return.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: If the pain returns, take two of the tablets with some water.
David could feel his anger returning.
when peace finally returns to this country
return.translation[0].definitions[2].not: In everyday English, people usually say that a feeling comes back rather than returns:
I’m worried that the pain will come back.
return.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to do something to someone because they have done the same thing to you
return.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: He smiled at her warmly and she returned his smile.
I phoned him twice on Friday and left messages, but he never returned my call (=he didn’t phone me).
Thanks very much. I’ll return the favour (=do something to help you) some day.
The police did not return fire (=shoot back at someone who shot at them).
return.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to hit the ball back to your opponent in a game such as tennis
return.translation[0].definitions[6].def: to elect someone to a political position, especially to represent you in parliament
return.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: Yeo was returned to Parliament with an increased majority.
At the election, she was returned as MP for Brighton.
return.translation[0].definitions[6].not: Return is usually passive in this meaning
return.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: The group returned increased profits last year.
return.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 4: to do something to someone because they have done the same thing to you
return.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: I left a message but he hasn't returned my call.
She kept her eyes fixed on the floor, refusing to return his gaze.
Sadly, she could never return his love.
Thanks a lot. I hope I'll be able to return the favour.
One plane opened fire on the American aircraft, which immediately returned fire.
return.translation[0].note_box[1].items[: The writer returned to his home town many years later
Hardy returned to his house in the country
The writer returned his home town
When she returned home that night, there was a letter for her
return.translation[0].note_box[2].sectio: to go back or come back to a place where you were before. Return sounds more formal than go back  or come back, and is more commonly used in written English
She returned to the hotel hoping to find a message.
Alastair returned from the office late that night.
On Friday, I returned home around six o'clock.
go back
to go to the place where you were before, or to the place where you usually live
It’s cold out here – shall we go back inside?
When are you going back to Japan?
go home
to go to your home again, or to the country where you were born, after you have been away from it
I did a bit of shopping and then went home.
Are you going home to Hong Kong when the course finishes?
come back
to come to the place where you are again, after going away from it
I’ll be away for two days – coming back on Thursday night.
He’s just come back from a vacation in Miami.
get back
to arrive somewhere where you were before, especially your home or the place where you are staying
We got back at about 9 o'clock.
She couldn’t wait to get back to London.
turn back
to turn around and go back in the direction you came from
We took the wrong road and had to turn back.
He ordered the soldiers to turn back and march south.
return.translation[1].definitions[0].def: the act of returning from somewhere, or your arrival back in a place
return.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: We’re all looking forward to your return!
I need to know the date of her return from Europe.
Malcolm decided to delay his return to York.
On his return from Canada, he joined the army.
return.translation[1].definitions[1].def: the act of giving, putting, or sending something back
return.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: A mother is appealing for the safe return of her baby son.
Police have arranged for the return of the stolen goods.
return.translation[1].definitions[2].def: a change back to a previous state or situation
return.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: The United States called for a return to democracy.
return.translation[1].definitions[3].def: when someone starts an activity again after they had stopped
return.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: Rose’s return to the teaching profession
Jean is well enough now to consider her return to work.
return.translation[1].definitions[4].def: the amount of profit that you get from something
return.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: The markets are showing extremely poor returns.
The average rates of return were 15%.
How can you get the best return on your investment?
The returns from farming are declining.
return.translation[1].definitions[5].def: the key that you press on a computer at the end of an instruction or to move to a new line
return.translation[1].definitions[5].exa: Key in the file name and press return.
return.translation[1].definitions[6].def: a ticket for a journey from one place to another and back again
return.translation[1].definitions[6].exa: Can I have a return to London please?
return.translation[1].definitions[7].def: when a feeling, situation etc starts to exist or happen again
return.translation[1].definitions[7].exa: She felt a return of her old anxiety.
David had noticed the return of worrying symptoms in the last few days.
return.translation[1].definitions[8].def: a statement giving written information in reply to official questions
return.translation[1].definitions[8].exa: an analysis of the 1851 census returns
return.translation[1].definitions[9].exa: What are the returns from last night’s voting?
return.translation[2].definitions[0].def: used or paid for a journey from one place to another and back again
return.translation[3].definitions[0].def: if an investment returns a particular amount of money, that is the amount of profit it makes
return.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: This high-performing fund has returned 20.8% a year on average over the past decade.
return.translation[3].definitions[1].def: to take a product back to the shop you bought it from to get your money back, or to get other goods in exchange for it
return.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: Any product purchased from Milo may be returned for a full refund.
return.translation[3].definitions[2].def: to go back to a previous activity or state
return.translation[3].definitions[2].exa: The mine returned to production in November.
The striking teachers have nowreturned to work.
return.translation[3].definitions[3].def: if you return a telephone call, you telephone someone because they have telephoned you
return.translation[3].definitions[3].exa: The minister didn’t return a call asking for comments on the crisis.
return.translation[3].definitions[4].def: if a bank returns a cheque, it refuses to pay it because there is not enough money in the account to do so
return.translation[3].definitions[4].exa: If we have to return a cheque, a charge of £15 will be made.
return.translation[3].definitions[5].def: if a JURY in a law case returns its VERDICT, it says whether it thinks someone is guilty or not
return.translation[4].definitions[0].def: the amount of profit made from an investment
return.translation[4].definitions[0].exa: British government bonds have produced a total return of 8.52% so far this month.
a slump affecting the returns from investment
return.translation[4].definitions[1].def: when someone or something goes back to a previous activity or state
return.translation[4].definitions[1].exa: Favorable government rates have aided the company’s return to profitability.
the return of petroleum prices to the highest levels since mid-February
return.translation[4].definitions[2].def: an official form that is filled in and sent to the tax authorities so they can calculate how much tax is owed
return.translation[4].definitions[2].exa: Over 12.2 million taxpayersfiled federal returns electronically this year.
allegations that the company had falsified its corporate tax return
return.translation[4].definitions[3].def: the button that is pressed on a computer KEYBOARD when you have finished typing an instruction
return.translation[4].definitions[3].exa: Enter the filename and press Return.
return.translation[4].definitions[4].def: the act of taking or sending back a product you have bought, in order to get your money back or to get other goods in exchange
return.translation[4].definitions[4].exa: We accept any return for any reason and will refund or replace the product.
Our customer service department deals with product returns.
return.translation[5].definitions[0].def: a ticket etc that allows you to travel to a place and back again
return.translation[5].definitions[0].exa: The package includes the return air fare from the UK and accommodation.
